After reading all of these comments, my impression is that George
Steinbrenner was,and his family are either jealous or afraid of being forgotten. I come to that conclusion because of the many things named after George Steinbrenner, the destruction of Yankee Stadium with no shred of it left, and the huge plaque of George
Steinbrenner in Monument Park.

George Steinbrenner made his mark in Yankee and baseball history.
As a Yankees fan, I'm very grateful for the pennants and World Series wins he brought us.

Babe Ruth, Lou Gehrig, Mickey Mantle, and others made their own marks as well, as have many others. To totally destroy original Yankee Stadium was dead wrong. It embodied much of New York's great history.

The current Yankee Stadium has a statue of George Steinbrenner. Babe Ruth saved baseball and is the God of baseball. A statue of Babe, and hopefully other Yankee greats would not detract from the
Steinbrenner legacy of winning baseball, nor would such masterpieces be something for the Steinbrenner family to fear.

There's room for the Steinbrenners, the Babe, and others. They all come under the title, "New York Yankees." The Yankees have the greatest history in the world of sports. I'm proud of that history and would be even prouder if the fear of Babe Ruth's ghost would not rule
decisions in a detrimental way, as has been done in the past. There is room and deserved pride for everyone. Relish the Babe. He made the Yankees the Yankees. You can't fight a ghost.

I do agree with you that I think it's rude to leave the generic voicemail, though. How do you know you haven't misdialed if you don't hear your friend's voice or name? If it's someone I'm calling that I don't know, I'm hoping this is their voicemail, but I don't know for sure...

This isn't about age, it's about class. I wonder how many of the interview subjects are first-generation professionals. Certainly no one who (just to pick two likely markers) to an old prep school or a private college would say thank-you notes are annoying intrusions. Maybe there still is upward mobility in the United States. Maybe too much.

I don't understand how the article was written without mentioning the term "NRN". That puts more control in the hands of the person who wants no reply.

Actually, I'd disagree that these people (Nick, Jake, etc.) are really communicating 'more.'  Rather, they are mostly talking at and past each other in waves of mostly meaningless words.  A sort of 'sound and fury, signifying nothing' situation.   In the Victorian era, they probably actually communicated 'more.'

Jake says, and Nick agrees, "as a society we communicate a lot more than we used to (or, at least, the younger half of us do)...

Exactly. Seventeen year old Nick is communicating more than he did five or six years ago. But as a society, more than others in generations before? Depends on how you define communication. In terms of number of devices used, sure. In terms of time spent? I doubt it. In terms of quality and depth of communication? This I really doubt.

Each generation in its youth believes it has invented what's important (read: communication, sex...). And it also seems each generation, as it ages, finds the proud, definite, sharp edges of the young irritating. Let's just hope today's young people, Nick and Jake included, remember that in 40 or 50 years.
Nick, are you listening to your thoughtful, considerate readers? They are telling you: slow down long enough to politely respond to those people in your life who are most important to you.

I really hope this was written in the spirit of Jonathan Swift.

If Nick Bilton finds a "thank you" email to be burdensome, then the onus is him to explain how, in the digital age, he himself feels when a kind, helpful email he has taken the time to craft goes unanswered.  What are his suggestions for forging the kind of polite rituals so fundamental to human interaction? Or should we suspend with them altogether? No more thank yous for a birthday present or for a kind gesture? Bilton's article is interesting enough in characterizing digital behaviors today.  But I still believe there is something perverse in his defense of the attitudes that underly ignoring a friend, a love-one, or a professor who has take time to reach out to you.

Crescent Dunes Solar Energy Project : 110 MWe maximum capacity, 52% capacity factor, cost $1 billion, land area 6km squared

Average US coal power generation in 2010 : 211 GWe

Average US natural gas generation in 2010 : 113 GWe

We need 5684 Crescent Dunes to replace coal and natural gas, at a cost of $5.7 trillion dollars. If we just aim to replace 20% of coal and natural gas then it takes $1.1 trillion dollars to do it. That is my back-of-the-envelop calculation.

Dear Energy User,

Your napkin calculations have some basic flaws. For one thing, Crescent Dunes is a relatively small plant. Just as, at one time, there was only one light bulb, there will be one CST plant in the U.S. in 2014. Once people see it, and the light bulb goes off in their heads, there will soon be many more, and many with much greater capacity.

Second, you assume that there will be no reduction on the demand side — no negawatts.

Third, you assume that CST in and of itself needs to be the only alternative energy solution, rather than becoming the major supplier for the southwest (including southern California) while also serving as the country's electrical storage system to deal with base load issues — much of the remaining electricity generated via local renewables and transmitted via a national smart grid.

Ramp up your imagination — we need solutions, not more coal and gas.

Mr. Gillis,

Please allow me to introduce you to concentrated solar thermal power (CST). CST plants can deliver solar electricity 24/7/365 using heat energy stored in environmentally benign molten salts during the day. No more baseload problems. This electricity can be transmitted via high-tension D.C. lines for 1,500 miles with a 10% voltage drop. Enough sunlight strikes the world's deserts each day to power all of civilization 6,000 times over. Enough sunlight strikes the Southwestern desert to power all of North America several hundred times over.

A CST plant, Gemasolar, has been operating in Spain for two years. Another is being built in Nevada and will come online in 2014. Several Destetec (google it) approved projects are being built in Spain and North Africa, and Desertic is busy designing Middle Eastern and European super grids.

CST makes nuclear and all fossil fuels obsolete. It can no doubt be improved over time, but it needs no fundamental technological breakthroughs to operate cost effectively — LCOE is competitive and, if externalized costs are considered, it is far, far superior to nuclear of fossil fuel power of any type.

CST is rapidly and inexpensively deployable and almost entirely environmentally benign. Please study it before you make statements such as:

"But a lot of energy analysts have crunched the numbers and concluded that today’s renewables, important as they are, cannot get us even halfway there."

www.ecotecture.com

I sincerely don't know what has happened to the idea of changing unhealthy behavior through public educational campaigns versus through despotic legislation. When I was a child, there was a large emphasis on teaching nutrition and portion sizes in school as well as on fostering physical education. But, yes, I forget that Mr. Bloomberg couldn't care less about such initiatives--favoring test prep and cutting out everything which might help the obesity epidemic from where it starts in childhood. When I taught special Ed students in the so called "food desert" of bed stuy, Brooklyn, education of this sort helped a great deal. One child in the beginning stages of type 2 diabetes loved learning about nutrition and Counting calories. Sad to say the standardized curriculum wouldn't allow for the time I was able to spend on the topic. Mr. Mayor, the "peasants" discover change through education, and I still believe that in spite of how much public policy has changed over the past 20 years.
